content: The Act titled "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2005" expands the deduction for interest on education loans. The "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2005" expands the deduction for interest on education loans by repealing the dollar limitation and increasing the phaseout beginning point based on modified adjusted gross income. The "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2005" eliminates the dollar limit on the deduction for interest on education loans and raises the phaseout threshold based on modified adjusted gross income. The "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2005" eliminates the dollar limit on the deduction for interest on education loans and raises the phaseout threshold based on modified adjusted gross income. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. SEC. 3. Deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses made permanent. Repeal of termination of Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Effective date applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4. Education savings accounts. SEC. 4. EDUCATION SAVINGS ACCOUNTS. Increase in allowable contributions to $5,000. Reports must be filed by June 30 of the following year. Effective date for amendments is after December 31, 2005. SEC. 5. Allowance of room, board, and special needs services for scholarships and tuition reduction programs in higher education. In amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, qualified scholarship definitions are expanded to include qualified higher education expenses for enrollment at eligible educational institutions. The terms 'qualified higher education expenses' and 'eligible educational institution' are defined in section 529(e). Special rules for teaching and research assistants regarding tuition reduction programs are also modified. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding qualified scholarship definitions to cover qualified higher education expenses at eligible educational institutions. Special rules for teaching and research assistants regarding tuition reduction programs are also adjusted. Effective December 31, 2005, expenses for education after this date are eligible for these changes. SEC. 6. Treatment of prepayment and savings plans in student financial aid analysis. Treatment of prepayment and savings plans in student financial aid analysis is amended to exclude qualified education benefits as assets of the student under section 475. Qualified education benefits are defined as programs meeting specific requirements under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines qualified education benefits as programs meeting specific requirements, including section 529 and 530 accounts. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 exclude certain financial assistance from student aid analysis, effective for academic years starting on or after July 1, 2006. Expansion of educational expenses allowed under the Hope Scholarship Credit is addressed in Section 7. Expansion of qualified tuition and related expenses for the Hope Scholarship Credit now includes fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for courses at eligible educational institutions. Additionally, the Hope Scholarship Credit will not be reduced by Federal Pell Grants and Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants. The Hope Scholarship Credit now covers fees, books, supplies, and equipment for courses at eligible educational institutions. Pell and SEOG grants will not reduce the credit. Expenses paid after December 31, 2005, for education in academic periods after that date are eligible. Title IX of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 exempts subtitles A, B, and D of title IV from the sunset provisions.
